content: The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" may be cited as the short title. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines key terms such as the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, design-basis threat, and formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material. The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines terms like Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and nuclear weapon. It also specifies formula quantities for strategic special nuclear material. The Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006 defines a nuclear weapon as any device utilizing atomic energy for use as a weapon, prototype, or test device. It was signed in 1968 and came into force in 1970. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and additional efforts are needed to reduce this threat. The White House's 2006 National Strategy for Combating Terrorism emphasizes the importance of addressing weapons of mass destruction. The White House's 2006 National Strategy for Combating Terrorism highlights the grave threat of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of terrorists. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan warns that a nuclear terror attack could have devastating global consequences, including widespread death, economic turmoil, and increased poverty. UN Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) emphasizes the need to combat terrorism by all means possible. United Nations Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) emphasizes the need for countries to adopt and enforce laws prohibiting non-state actors from acquiring and using weapons of mass destruction for terrorist purposes. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Dr. Mohammed El Baradei, warns of the urgent need to prevent terrorist attacks using nuclear weapons. The sense of Congress on preventing nuclear terrorism is emphasized. The sense of Congress emphasizes the need for a comprehensive approach to reduce the threat of nuclear terror, including efforts to eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons, secure nuclear materials globally, and enhance the ability to detect and prevent terrorist activities. The sense of Congress highlights the importance of a comprehensive strategy to reduce the threat of nuclear terrorism, emphasizing the need to secure all nuclear weapons and materials globally. The President should prioritize preventing a nuclear terrorist attack on the United States and accelerate relevant programs. The President should accelerate programs to prevent nuclear terrorism, secure nuclear materials, and combat nuclear smuggling. The International Atomic Energy Agency should be funded appropriately to coordinate international efforts in this regard. Legislation sponsored by Senator Richard Lugar is also important in this context. Legislation sponsored by Senator Richard Lugar, Senator Pete Domenici, and former Senator Sam Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. Senator Richard Lugar, Senator Pete Domenici, and former Senator Sam Nunn sponsored legislation that led to the creation of a senior advisor to the president for the prevention of nuclear terrorism, as outlined in an amendment to the National Security Act of 1947. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is appointed by the President with Senate approval and is responsible for advising on nuclear terrorism matters and formulating US policies to prevent nuclear terrorism. This includes developing plans with measurable milestones to enhance prevention efforts. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is responsible for advising on nuclear terrorism matters and formulating US policies to prevent nuclear terrorism. This includes developing plans with measurable milestones and targets for departments and agencies to prevent nuclear terrorism by finding gaps, inefficiencies, and overseeing program implementation strategies and budget requests. The Senior Advisor to the President oversees program implementation strategies, budget requests, and new initiatives to prevent nuclear terrorism. They also coordinate US efforts to implement policies and may appoint necessary personnel. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism may appoint personnel as necessary to fulfill their duties and is designated as a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism may appoint personnel as necessary and is a member of the National Security Council. An annual report is required. The President, in consultation with the Senior Advisor for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, must submit an annual report to Congress on the security of strategic special nuclear material. The report includes details on the program for removal and security of nuclear weapons and materials as established by the Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act. The Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act requires an annual report to Congress on the security of nuclear weapons and materials, including a survey of global sites with nuclear materials and a list of high-priority sites for removal or security measures. The annual report to Congress on nuclear security includes a plan for securing or removing nuclear weapons and materials from vulnerable sites worldwide. The annual report to Congress on nuclear security includes a plan for securing nuclear material, radiological materials, and related equipment at vulnerable facilities worldwide, efforts to establish security standards, and a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The United States policy is to ensure the security and accountability of all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. This includes adhering to international nuclear security standards outlined in various treaties and resolutions. The President, through the Senior Advisor for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, is responsible for implementing these measures. The President, with the Senior Advisor for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, seeks global agreement on nuclear security standards to protect against terrorist threats, considering equipment limitations and ensuring verifiability. The President, through the Senior Advisor for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, collaborates internationally to enhance nuclear security measures in countries with nuclear weapons or special nuclear material, ensuring compliance with established standards. The President collaborates internationally to upgrade security measures in countries with nuclear weapons or special nuclear material, ensuring sustained compliance with established standards and providing financial and technical assistance for security upgrades. Additionally, efforts are made to work with other countries to establish effective nuclear security rules, regulation, and enforcement. Effective nuclear security rules and enforcement, including a regulatory design-basis threat model, should be implemented globally for all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials to counter threats from terrorists and criminals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008: $50,000,000 to increase international participation in converting nuclear facilities from highly enriched uranium to low enriched uranium and to remove highly enriched uranium from such facilities.
